posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: I got prompted with this error message after restarting my computer. I hit “Copy error and quit” but it doesn’t actually copy and error. I’m wondering if anyone knows how to fix this before I go and bother Signal Support. Thanks in advance.

link_counts.title: Help us test desktop history syncing!

posts.cooked: This is an issue with the flatpak from flathub. To recover you need a backup of your database key. There is some guidance to restore here: Database Error · Issue #723 · flathub/org.signal.Signal · GitHub
I have added more detailed instructions here: WARNING: Do not update from flathub! Database error

link_counts.title: Troubleshooting Guide: Database Error after Flatpak Update from Flathub

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Damn, that does seem to be my issue. I installed the Flatpak about a year ago before I knew it was unofficial. Is there no way whatsoever to restore from this state without a backup? I see 2 entries in Key Rack for Signal. Could one of these help me get back to a working state without having to lose all my messages?

Definitely make a backup of your Signal install and the keys.

tar -cvzf ~/signal-bu.tgz ~/.var/app/org.signal.Signal

Have a look here for a go at decrypting the key.

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop

Login keyring password prompt after upgrading to 7.16.0

opened 03:58AM - 20 Jul 24 UTC
closed 08:47AM - 03 Aug 24 UTC
beantaco
Linux

### Using a supported version? - [X] I have searched searched open and closed i…ssues for duplicates. - [X] I am using Signal-Desktop as provided by the Signal team, not a 3rd-party package. ### Overall summary After upgrading to 7.16.0, I see a login keyring password prompt. > The login keyring did not get unlocked when you logged into your computer. Signal doesn't launch until the prompt goes away, but I can hit the cancel button multiple times to make that happen. This issue has existed before (#5914). 1. What is the cause of the issue? 2. What should users do in the meantime? 3. If needed, when will Signal developers release a fix? ### Steps to reproduce 1. Attempt to launch Signal. ### Expected result Signal launches immediately. ### Actual result The login prompt appears, and Signal does not launch. ### Screenshots _No response_ ### Signal version 7.16.0 ### Operating system Debian based ### Version of Signal on your phone _No response_ ### Link to debug log _No response_

Download the AppImage of Electron Fiddle, clear everything from all four panes, paste in the script to the “Main Process” window, and update the “folder” path to /home/{your_user_name}/.var/app/org.signal.Signal/config/Signal

image1480×1038 158 KB

Click run, check the console output. If it works, check the /home/{your_user_name}/.var/app/org.signal.Signal/config/Signal folder. You should see a config.json.bak file with encryptedKey, and config.json with key.

link_counts.title: Login keyring password prompt after upgrading to 7.16.0 · Issue #6944 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Thanks so much for the info, I really appreciate it! You mentioned originally that I need a backup for any chance at recovering my messages, but I don’t have a backup. Will this method still work for me?

I also have no backup. When I reinstalled or updated Signal, I noticed all my phone Signal data was gone. Now the Database Error totally stops usage of Signal on the desktop. Where might a backup be and how to make the Desktop Signal program work please?

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
kmf.13:

Where might a backup be

If you didn’t make a backup manually, then unfortunately you won’t have one.

kmf.13:

and how to make the Desktop Signal program work please?

@Grevvy seems more knowledgeable about this issue. Hopefully we can get some more clarification soon about what users without backups can do.
How does one make a backup?
To make a backup: tar -cvzf ~/signal-backup.tgz ~/.var/app/org.signal.Signal

If you have not made a backup, there is still a chance we will be able to recover chat history in a few days. The broken update wrote a key to the keyring in a different format than Signal is expecting, and this might be recoverable.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Hey, @Grevvy any update on this? I see 2 keys under Signal in Key Rack. One of them is named “Chrome Safe Storage Control” and the other is named “Chromium Safe Storage” and the other is named “Chromium Safe Storage” and appears to be some base64 encoded text. What are the odds I can just copy and paste that value into my Signal config and make it work again?

Troubleshooting Guide: Database Error after Flatpak Update from Flathub Desktop Discussion
Some instructions to potentially recover message history. Try this if you’re getting the “contact Signal support” database error. If you’re getting the “keystore has changed” error, see the first post in this thread for troubleshooting. Make a backup if you haven’t already tar -cvzf ~/signal-backup.tgz ~/.var/app/org.signal.Signal Install Key Rack from Flathub. Open Key Rack, click Signal (2 keys), open Chromium Safe Storage, and copy the key. Add it to the normal keyring with secret-tool sto…

Give it a go!

link_counts.title: Troubleshooting Guide: Database Error after Flatpak Update from Flathub

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
Hey @Grevvy, I greatly appreciate all your support. For some reason this did not work for me. I followed your steps exactly, extracted the base64 value from Key Rack and pasted it in using secret-tool. However, I get the same popup. Since I launched Signal from the terminal as you said to do in your steps, I got some errors, I don’t think they would be particularly useful though.

Below are the relevant errors from the log.

2024-10-13 07:16:07.844: ERROR CORE sqlcipher_page_cipher: hmac check failed for pgno=1
2024-10-13 07:16:07.844: ERROR CORE sqlite3Codec: error decrypting page 1 data: 1
2024-10-13 07:16:07.844: ERROR CORE sqlcipher_codec_ctx_set_error 1
{"level":40,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:07.845Z","msg":"MainSQL: Database log code=26: file is not a database in \"PRAGMA journal_mode = WAL\""}
{"level":30,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:07.845Z","msg":"MainSQL: migrateDatabase: Migration without cipher change failed"}
2024-10-13 07:16:07.873: ERROR CORE sqlcipher_page_cipher: hmac check failed for pgno=1
2024-10-13 07:16:07.873: ERROR CORE sqlite3Codec: error decrypting page 1 data: 1
2024-10-13 07:16:07.873: ERROR CORE sqlcipher_codec_ctx_set_error 1
{"level":40,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:07.873Z","msg":"MainSQL: Database log code=26: statement aborts at 2: [PRAGMA user_version] file is not a database"}
{"level":50,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:07.873Z","msg":"MainSQL: Database startup error: SqliteError: file is not a database\n    at Database.pragma ([REDACTED]/node_modules/@signalapp/better-sqlite3/lib/methods/pragma.js:11:31)\n    at getUserVersion ([REDACTED]/ts/sql/util.js:132:13)\n    at migrateSchemaVersion ([REDACTED]/ts/sql/Server.js:404:54)\n    at openAndMigrateDatabase ([REDACTED]/ts/sql/Server.js:436:5)\n    at openAndSetUpSQLCipher ([REDACTED]/ts/sql/Server.js:458:14)\n    at initialize ([REDACTED]/ts/sql/Server.js:496:10)\n    at MessagePort.<anonymous> ([REDACTED]/ts/sql/mainWorker.js:69:41)\n    at [nodejs.internal.kHybridDispatch] (node:internal/event_target:820:20)\n    at MessagePort.<anonymous> (node:internal/per_context/messageport:23:28)"}
{"level":50,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:07.873Z","msg":"Failed to get zoom factor {\"name\":\"SqliteError\"}"}
{"level":30,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:08.098Z","msg":"got fast theme-setting value system"}
{"level":50,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:08.449Z","msg":"sql.initialize was unsuccessful; returning early"}
{"level":30,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:08.450Z","msg":"close event {\"readyForShutdown\":false,\"shouldQuit\":false}"}
{"level":30,"time":"2024-10-13T11:16:08.450Z","msg":"maybeRequestCloseConfirmation: Checking to see if close confirmation is needed"}

I feel like there’s got to be a way to decrypt it since I literally have the key written, I just don’t exactly know which specific steps to do to decrypt it.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Maybe it’s possible to use a tool like cyberchef to decrypt the “encryptedKey” and then just store the original key in the config.json?

So far it hasn’t worked for anybody. You can use the Fiddler snippet from before to recreate the plaintext database key from the encryptedKey in config.json and the org.signal.Signal keyring password, but that shouldn’t make any difference.

link_counts.title: Login keyring password prompt after upgrading to 7.16.0 · Issue #6944 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
I don’t think that will work, I will try it later though just to check. Do we know how the key encrypts the “encryptedkey” exactly? I don’t want to go digging through the source code if I don’t have to. I think something like cyberchef might be really useful in restoring the original key from they key in key rack and the encryptedkey.

I got an error when trying to use the Electron Fiddle code unfortunately.

I think I might try manually decrypting the key myself. Is it known how the key is encrypted? What cipher is used? Is any additional encoding/decoding required? Also, what is the output key supposed to look like? Will it also be a base64 encoded string?

I might spend some time looking through the repo myself, but I’d prefer to save the trouble if someone knowledgeable would be able to share the info instead.
posts.edit_reason: 2 posts were merged in by Herohtar

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: I’m about to give up on this and just reinstall my Signal app. I really didn’t want to lose the message history as it is very useful, but I can’t find a solution unfortunately. Does anyone have any information on how this might be possible before I give up? Thanks in advance.

There doesn’t seem to be much interest in trying to recover the old key. The base64 encoded decryption key in the keyring is serialized with some other stuff before being encrypted.

From rereading this thread I’m not hopeful that there’s a way to recover it.

We can only hope Signal implements the long-awaited encrypted cloud backups soon!

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Agreed. I think I’ll be giving up now sadly. It looks like there was some significant progress recently on the cloud backups, so hopefully we’ll be able to recover our lost messages on desktop clients soon.
